mets:mets.LABEL: Exterior of the May Company in Irwin, Colorado

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Exterior of the May Company in Irwin, Colorado

mods:physicalDescription.mods:extent: 1 item (photograph), 8 x 10 inches, black and white
mods:physicalDescription.mods:note: On envelope: ''# 119 The May Co. Irwin, Colorado''. On the front of photograph: ''Irwin Colo - 1879-1880''. Handwritten on back of photograph: "#119 May Co Irwin, CO, 1879-80."

mods:mods.mods:abstract: View down main street of Irwin, Colorado. Exterior of an early May Company wood building can be seen in the left of the photograph with a sign that reads: ''D. May & Co. Square Dealing Clothing Room.'' David May immigrated to Colorado from Bavaria and started his first clothing store in Leadville in 1877. After 1877 David May opened branches of his store in Irwin (1881), Gunnison (1881), Aspen (Johnston & Co. 1886), Glenwood Springs (Manhattan Store, 1887), and Denver (April 12, 1889). The May Company evolved into one of the largest department store chains in the United States.
mods:mods.mods:note: Appears in ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, page 28.
Donated by May D and F.
mods:mods.mods:accessCondition: Copyright restrictions may apply. User is responsible for all copyright compliance.

mets:mets.LABEL: Interior View of the Star Bakery

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Interior View of the Star Bakery

mods:physicalDescription.mods:extent: 1 item (photograph), 9 x 6 inches, black and white
mods:physicalDescription.mods:note: Printed on the page below the photograph: "Star Bakery, 2744 W. Colfax in Denver, was founded by Eva and Jacob Boscowitz in 1907., Pictured left to right: Rudy Boscowitz (Boscoe), Elya Rubin, Eva Boscowitz Rubin, Sam Boscowitz (Boscoe), Courtesy: Jay Boscoe, Sponsors: Mr. and Mrs. Jay Boscoe, Mr. and Mrs. Rudolph Boscoe."

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Members of the Boscowitz and Rubin families stand in the Star Bakery store surrounded by loaves of bread. Pictured from left to right are Rudy Boscowitz (Boscoe), Elya (Eli) Rubin, Eva Boscowitz Rubin and Sam Boscowitz (Boscoe). Located at 2744 West Colfax in Denver, Colorado, the Star Bread Company (operating as Star Bakery) was founded by East European immigrants Eva and Jacob Boscowitz in 1907. After her husband's death in 1909, Eva Boscowitz continued to operate the store, later marrying another baker, Elya (Eli) Rubin. The boys changed their names to Rudy Boscoe and Sam Boscoe, eventually taking over and operating the business until the 1970s.
mods:mods.mods:note: Appears in ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, page 40.
Copy donated by Jay Boscoe for ''A Colorado Jewish Family Album.''
mods:mods.mods:accessCondition: Copyright restrictions may apply. User is responsible for all copyright compliance.

mets:mets.LABEL: The Shwayder Brothers Standing on a Samsonite Suitcase

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: The Shwayder Brothers Standing on a Samsonite Suitcase

mods:physicalDescription.mods:extent: 2 item (photograph), 10 x 8 inches,
mods:physicalDescription.mods:note: On envelope: "# 160. Shwayder Bros. standing on suitcase." On back of photograph, "#160, The five Shwayder Brothers standing on suitcase to show strength of 'Samson' case 1910. Famous advertising display. Donor Samsonite Corp." Stamp on back of photograph: "Negative Filed at Samsonite Photo Lab." Printers instructions.

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The five Shwayder brothers stand on a board that is balanced on a Samsonite suitcase to demonstrate the strength of the suitcase. Jesse Shwayder is pictured second from the right. Other Shwayder brothers are: Mark, Maurice, Benjamin and Solomon. The Shwayder brothers owned Shwayder Trunk Company, which later became known as the Samsonite Corporation. The photograph was used to advertise Samsonite luggage.
mods:mods.mods:note: Appears in ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, page 34.
mods:mods.mods:accessCondition: Copyright restrictions may apply. User is responsible for all copyright compliance.

mets:mets.LABEL: Interior of Isaacs' Hardware Store in Leadville

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Interior of Isaacs' Hardware Store in Leadville

mods:physicalDescription.mods:extent: 1 item (photograph), 5 x 8 inches,
mods:physicalDescription.mods:note: Handwritten on envelope: "167 Isaac's Hardware Store, Leadville, c 1909." Handwritten on back of photograph: "#167, Hyman Isaac's Hardware Store in Leadville btn 4th and 5th (420?) Harrison Ave. c. 1909, See Leadville file for description."

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Interior view of Hyman Isaacs' Hardware Store in Leadville, Colorado. There is an unidentified man in the center of the photograph who is leaning against a counter.
mods:mods.mods:note: Newspaper article with the photo titled ''Leadville Woman has Oldest Range in Rocky Mountains'' (undated) states that two individuals, Eva Zelezniker and Joe Matekal, owned the two oldest working Monarch coal ranges in the Rocky Mountain region. Monarch gave her a new electric range and him an electric griddle. The coal ranges had been purchased in Hyman Isaacs store in the early 1900s and had been advertised by Isaacs in the Herald Democrat as the ''Stay Satisfactory'' range.
Appears in ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, page 117.
mods:mods.mods:accessCondition: Copyright restrictions may apply. User is responsible for all copyright compliance.

mets:mets.LABEL: Interior of Stein Retail Store and Employees

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Interior of Stein Retail Store and Employees

mods:physicalDescription.mods:extent: 1 item (photograph), 8 x 10 inches,
mods:physicalDescription.mods:note: Handwritten on envelope:"# 386 Stein family of Pueblo, 1900-1960 info inside." Photocopy of handwritten note inside original envelope: ''Taken in Pueblo, Colorado between 1913 and 1914. Max Stein arrived in Pueblo in 1898 (he is the man on the right) after serving as a mounted policeman, he began peddling fruit and vegetables from a wagon. About 1910 he opened a retail grocery store at 1156 4th St., Pueblo. The business is still in the same location but has expanded to become a wholesale food company. Marvin Stein, the present owner, is a third-generation Stein.'' Handwritten note on back of photocopy: '' Photo prior to (illegible), Stein Retail Store, L to R: Jim Chavez, John Myers, W.C. ''Bill'' Ohlman, Billy Sisson, Albert Stein, ''B'' Blackburn, Emanuel Stein, Minnie Stein, Max Stein."

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Employees of the Stein Retail store in Pueblo, Colorado. The employees are standing inside the store and there are various items for sale around them. From left to right: Jim Chavez, John Myers, W.C. ''Bill'' Ohlman, Billy Sisson, Albert Stein, ''B'' Blackburn, Emanuel Stein, Minnie Stein, Max Stein.

mets:mets.LABEL: Portrait of Jesse Shwayder

mods:physicalDescription.mods:extent: 1 item (photograph), 10 x 7 inches, black and white
mods:physicalDescription.mods:note: Handwritten on envelope: "#30 Jesse Shwayder, Founder of Samsonite Co., c. 1929." Handwritten on back of photograph: "#30, Portrait of Jesse Shwayder, founder of Samsonite Corporation circa 1929, donated by Mr. Gordon Rosenblum."

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Formal portrait of Jesse Shwayder standing with his hands in his pockets. In the early 1900s, Jesse Shwayder opened a small luggage factor in Denver with his father, Isaac, and brothers Mark, Maurice, Benjamin, and Solomon. Together they turned it into one of the largest luggage producers in America, the Samsonite Corporation.

mets:mets.LABEL: Label Ginsburg Standing in His Ginsburg's Grocery Store

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Label Ginsburg Standing in His Ginsburg's Grocery Store

mods:physicalDescription.mods:extent: 2 items (2 photographs), 5 x 7 inches, black and white
mods:physicalDescription.mods:note: Handwritten on envelope: "# 207 Label Ginsburg, in grocery store, c 1925 info inside check copy". Typewritten tag located inside original envelope: "Label Ginsberg In his grocery store Denver, C. 1925". Handwritten notes on back of photograph: "Approximately 1925 #207 MMJ 15 8/78 Mr. Louis Ginsburg (Verben) 14th at Grove St. Husband of Mollie Ginsburg. Father of :Rose Greenblatt (Mrs. Isadore Greenblatt 1576 Osceola) Dr. Hyman Ginsburg 3124 Van Ness Fresno, Calif 98704 Joe Ginsburg, Acct. 955 Eudora 80222 Picture sent in by: Faye Langer (Mrs. William Lauger) Mr. and Mrs. William Lauger 418 Swain Court Stockton, Calif 95207 5 5/16 x 3 5/8 Religion Cut Phillips Fri 9".

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Label Ginsburg is standing in front of Ginsburg's grocery counter wearing a suit and bowler hat. Canned and dry goods are displayed on the shelves as well as a large sign for Hills Brothers Coffee. The store was located at 1401 Grove St., Denver, Colorado in Denver's Westside Colfax Jewish community. When a sign painter made a mistake and spelled the Ginsberg surname with a "u" instead of an "e," Label changed the family name to Ginsburg.
mods:mods.mods:note: Appears in ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, page 43.
Donated by Dorothea Langer in September of 1978.
mods:mods.mods:accessCondition: Copyright restrictions may apply. User is responsible for all copyright compliance.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Opening of Dave Cook Sporting Goods Store, Denver, Colo.

mods:physicalDescription.mods:extent: 1 item (photograph), 8 x 10 inches, black and white
mods:physicalDescription.mods:note: On envelope: "#1034 Cooks Sporting Goods." Handwritten on back of photograph: "Opening of Dave Cook Sporting Goods, 1601 Larimer St store, 1936, Standing from left to right: Nate Bernstone, Dave Cook, Jane Cook, Herb Cook, Belle Smernoff."

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The staff of Dave Cook Sporting Goods stand in front of the counter next to baskets of flowers, celebrating the grand opening of the store at 1601 Larimer Street, Denver, Colorado. From left to right: Nate Bernstone, Dave Cook, Jane Cook, Herb Cook, and Belle Smernoff. In 1924, Dave and Max Cook went into the sporting goods business, operating the first major sports store in Colorado.
mods:mods.mods:note: Appears in, ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' By Dr. Jeanne Abrams on page 55.

mets:mets.LABEL: Maurice Epstein Cartoon

mods:physicalDescription.mods:extent: 1 item photograph, 10 x 8 inches, black and white
mods:physicalDescription.mods:note: On envelope: "#1049 Maurice Epstein." Caption on image: "Cartoon published in the Denver Post. Sunday, December 30, 1923."

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Cartoon of Maurice Epstein with a photograph head and cartoon body. He holds three caps and around him are more drawn pictures and writing. Counter clockwise from the top, ''Maurice likes to burn up the roads in his big Lincoln.'' On a billboard near a car, ''Imperial Caps 'Just a mile above the rest of 'em.''' On a sign, ''This is Mr. Epstein owner of Midwest Cap Wrks. Biggest cap factory west of Chicago!!'' Near a factory, ''''Imperial' Midwest Caps going to important centers.'' Trains traveling to San Fransisco, Los Angeles, and New Orleans. Finally, a man is walking away saying, ''Mine is a Midwest cap!''
mods:mods.mods:accessCondition: Copyright restrictions may apply. User is responsible for all copyright compliance.

mets:mets.LABEL: Marchick Store

mods:physicalDescription.mods:extent: 1 item (photograph), 8 x 10 inches, black and white
mods:physicalDescription.mods:note: On envelope: ''#1065 Lillian and Sam Marchick Sam and Ben Marchick.'' On back of photograph: ''Cheyenne, Wyoming Sam Marchick and Sons store, Sandy Viniks maternal grandfather, Same Marchick on left, his son Ben in center.'' On back of second photograph, #1065, Sam Marchick, Joe Marchick, Marchick & Son, Cheyenne.''

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Store owner Sam Marchick, left, his son in center, and an unidentified man and woman at right, in Marchick's Cheyenne, Wyoming store. A sign in back of large trunk reads "Shoe sale - pick em out." Another sign that is displayed between the two Marchick men, states, "Sale on pants." Samuel Marchick and his wife, Lillie (Rice), were born in Ostrovo, Poland. Sam Marchick came to the United States in 1904 and sent for his wife and children: Joseph, Benjamin, Jacob, Mary, Arline and Faye. The family operated a new and used clothing store and a pawn shop, and lived above the store.
mods:mods.mods:accessCondition: Copyright restrictions may apply. User is responsible for all copyright compliance.

mods:physicalDescription.mods:note: On envelope: "# 160. Shwayder Bros. standing on suitcase." On back of photograph, "Shwayder Bros. on 'Samson' suitcase, 1923."

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The five Shwayder brothers stand on a board that is balanced on a Samsonite suitcase to demonstrate the strength of the suitcase. Jesse Shwayder is pictured second from the right. Other Shwayder brothers are: Mark, Maurice, Benjamin and Solomon. The Shwayder brothers owned Shwayder Trunk Company, which later became known as the Samsonite Corporation. The photograph was used to advertise Samsonite luggage.

mets:mets.LABEL: Schachet Mercantile Company

mods:physicalDescription.mods:extent: 1 item (photograph), 5 x 7 inches, black and white
mods:physicalDescription.mods:note: Handwritten on envelope: ''#217 Schuachet Mercantile Co [sic]''. On back of photograph: ''#217 Schuchet [sic] Mercantile Company 1978 W. Colfax near Stor Briad Donor Charles McNamera West Side 2u.''

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Exterior view of the Schachet Mercantile Company on West Colfax Avenue in Denver, Colorado. The building was originally built as a saloon in 1896, rented by Eli Schachet and his sons in 1918 and served as the headquarters for their meat and fish store until it closed in 1981. Schachet came to Denver for his health and served the Jewish West Colfax neighborhood for many years as a ''schochet'' (ritual slaughterer for kosher meat). With his sons, he expanded his business to include smoked fish delicacies such as lox and sable. A close friend of Berel Manischewitz, the founder of the B. Manischewitz Company, a specialty food company that specialized in matzo, or unleavened bread, Schachet became the exclusive distributor for the newly formed Manischewitz Company products in Colorado and other western states. Bugsy Siegel ate at the delicatessen that was part of the Mercantile Co. when he was in Denver. The building currently houses Brooklyn's Sports Bar, and the production of smoked fish is now carried on in Edgewater, Colorado under the name Arctic Pacific Fisheries.
mods:mods.mods:accessCondition: Copyright restrictions may apply. User is responsible for all copyright compliance.

dc:dc.dc:title: Schachet Mercantile Company

The building was originally built as a saloon in 1896, rented by Eli Schachet and his sons in 1918 and served as the headquarters for their meat and fish store until it closed in 1981. Schachet came to Denver for his health and served the Jewish West Colfax neighborhood for many years as a ''schochet'' (ritual slaughterer for kosher meat). With his sons, he expanded his business to include smoked fish delicacies such as lox and sable. A close friend of Berel Manischewitz, the founder of the B. Manischewitz Company, a specialty food company that specialized in matzo, or unleavened bread, Schachet became the exclusive distributor for the newly formed Manischewitz Company products in Colorado and other western states. Bugsy Siegel ate at the delicatessen that was part of the Mercantile Co. when he was in Denver. The building currently houses Brooklyn's Sports Bar, and the production of smoked fish is now carried on in Edgewater, Colorado under the name Arctic Pacific Fisheries.
Donated by Charles McNamara.

mets:mets.LABEL: Exterior of the Meyer Dry Goods Store in Fort Collins, Colo. with Ida Meyer Seated in Front of the Building

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Exterior of the Meyer Dry Goods Store in Fort Collins, Colo. with Ida Meyer Seated in Front of the Building

mods:physicalDescription.mods:extent: 1 item (photograph), 5 x 7 inches, black and white
mods:physicalDescription.mods:note: On envelope: ''#741 Meyer Store in Ft. Collins''. On back of the photograph: ''The Meyer Store Fort Collins, 1908 Ida Meyer''.

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Two window displays and the words "The Meyer Store" appear at the bottom of the windows. Ida Meyer sits in front of the door in a long dress. She is seated next to a young boy (unidentified). The store was established by Ida's husband Sam Meyer in Fort Collins, Colorado in 1905. Ida and Sam Meyer were married in 1908 and both became active in the town's civic and social life.
mods:mods.mods:accessCondition: Copyright restrictions may apply. User is responsible for all copyright compliance.

mets:mets.LABEL: Exterior of M. Wise Store, Trinidad, Colo.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Exterior of M. Wise Store, Trinidad, Colo.

mods:physicalDescription.mods:extent: 1 item (photograph), 5 x 7 inches, black and white
mods:physicalDescription.mods:note: On back of photograph: #820 Please credit Colorado Historical Society commercial use requires additional fee. C. Trinidad-1860's''. On envelope: ''#820 M. Wise Store in Trinidad Caption. M. Wise store in Trinidad, Colorado, c. 1860s courtesy of the Colorado Historical Society''.

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The exterior of the M. Wise Store in Trinidad, Colorado, is shown with three men standing in front of the door before an unpaved street. The sign above the door reads, "M. Wise and Co." and advertises dry goods, clothing, liquor, and groceries. Three men stand further down the street. Maurice Wise may have been the first Jewish merchant in Trinidad.
mods:mods.mods:note: Courtesy of the Colorado Historical Society.
Appears in, ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' By Dr. Jeanne Abrams on page 122.
Gift of the Colorado Historical Society.

mods:physicalDescription.mods:note: On front of postcard: ''200 Blk. N. Main. June 3 1921 Pueblo Colo.'' On envelope: ''#1048 Bernheim/Bowman Family Businesses, Pueblo, Co. 1921''.

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Damage at Charles Bernheim's Woman's Outfitters resulting from the 1921 flood in Pueblo, Colorado. The store is shown with an overturned trolley in front of it. The store was located in the 200 block of North Main in Pueblo, Colorado.

mods:physicalDescription.mods:note: On envelope, ''#1030 Gordon Sign Co.'' On back of photograph, ''Gordon Sign Co. 1028 Detroit, 1028 Detroit, #1030, Gordon Sign.''

mets:mets.LABEL: Interior of Phil Brown's Kosher Butcher Shop

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Interior of Phil Brown's Kosher Butcher Shop

mods:physicalDescription.mods:extent: 2 items (photograph), 5 x 7 inches, black and white
mods:physicalDescription.mods:note: On envelope: " # 70 Phil Brown's Kosher Butcher Shop, C 1921." Handwritten on the back of on photograph: "#70, Phil Brown Kosher, Butcher Shop, circa 1921, Phil Brown behind counter, Mrs. Julia Brown." Handwritten on the back of the other photograph: "printers instruction, #70, Phil Brown's Kosher meat [crossed out] Butcher Ship, 1921, #70, Salimans - Bar & Grill [crossed out]."

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Phil Brown in white apron and hat, stands behind meat counter, with a customer in front of the counter. Bare light bulbs, stools in front of the counter and saw hanging on back wall are part of the interior. Phil Brown was a kosher butcher in Denver.
mods:mods.mods:accessCondition: Copyright restrictions may apply. User is responsible for all copyright compliance.

mets:mets.LABEL: A. Grossman's Haberdashery on Champa St.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A. Grossman's Haberdashery on Champa St.

mods:physicalDescription.mods:extent: 1 item (photograph), 5 x 7 inches, black and white
mods:physicalDescription.mods:note: On envelope: ''# 91 Abraham Grossman in his Haberdashery, 1920.'' On back of photograph, ''Abe Grossman's Man's Haberdashery, c. 1920's, Denver, #91, Grossman's." Printers instructions and an Encyclopaedia Judaica stamp.

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Abraham Grossman appears here in his store, the Grossman's Haberdashery, in Denver around 1920. Socks, shirts, and suspenders are on display hanging from shelves. The store was located on Sixteenth Street, Denver's main downtown business thoroughfare.
mods:mods.mods:accessCondition: Copyright restrictions may apply. User is responsible for all copyright compliance.

dc:dc.dc:title: A. Grossman's Haberdashery on Champa St.
dc:dc.dc:format: 1 item (photograph), 5 x 7 inches, black and white
dc:dc.dc:description: Title supplied by archivist.

On envelope: ''# 91 Abraham Grossman in his Haberdashery, 1920.'' On back of photograph, ''Abe Grossman's Man's Haberdashery, c. 1920's, Denver, #91, Grossman's." Printers instructions and an Encyclopaedia Judaica stamp.

Abraham Grossman appears here in his store, the Grossman's Haberdashery, in Denver around 1920. Socks, shirts, and suspenders are on display hanging from shelves. The store was located on Sixteenth Street, Denver's main downtown business thoroughfare.
Donated by Sydney Grossman.

Photograph caption, p. 41, Jewish Denver, 1859-1940. __Annie Orlinsky Miller and daughters Sara and Celia appear in front of Orlinsky's Grocery c. 1910.

mods:physicalDescription.mods:extent: 1 item (photograph), 5 x 4 inches, black and white
mods:physicalDescription.mods:note: Handwritten on envelope: "#309 Millers in front of Orlinsky's Grocery." Handwritten on front of photograph: "Annie Miller, Sarah & Celia." Handwritten on back of photograph: "#309 Annie Miller & daughters Sarah and Celia in front of Orlinsky Cash Grocery & Meat Market, 8th Ave & Mariposa."

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The Miller Family stands in front of the Orlinsky Cash Grocery and Meat Market. Annie Orlinsky Miller stands behind her daughters, Sarah and Celia. The store was located on 8th Avenue and Mariposa Street in Denver, Colorado. Annie Miller helped support her family by operating her own store.
mods:mods.mods:note: Appears in ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, page 41.
Copy donated by Milton Morris, a friend of the Orlinsky family.

mets:mets.LABEL: Interior of Stein's Market in Pueblo, Colorado

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Interior of Stein's Market in Pueblo, Colorado

mods:physicalDescription.mods:extent: 1 item (photograph), 4 x 5 inches, black and white
mods:physicalDescription.mods:note: Handwritten on envelope: ''# 386 Stein family of Pueblo, 1900-1960 info inside.'' Photocopy of handwritten note inside original envelope: ''Taken in Pueblo, Colorado between 1913 and 1914. Max Stein arrived in Pueblo in 1898 (he is the man on the right) after serving as a mounted policeman, he began peddling fruit and vegetables from a wagon. About 1910 he opened a retail grocery store at 1156 4th St., Pueblo. The business is still in the same location but has expanded to become a wholesale food company. Marvin Stein, the present owner, is a third-generation Stein. Handwritten notes on back of photograph: ''10-4-26 Pueblo Donated by Mrs. Ruth Stein #386.''

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Interior of Stein's Market in Pueblo, Colorado. The market was located at 115 East 4th Street. Two unidentified employees stand behind a counter and an unidentified woman stands in front of one of the counters.

dc:dc.dc:description: Title supplied by archivist.

Handwritten on envelope: ''#417 Gregori Mogilner Mattress Factory, Denver 1909 copy- slightly dif.'' On back of one photograph: ''Gregori (Harry) Mogilner, Abe's father, making mattresses in Denver factory 1909. In 1925 he moved to Colorado Springs and bought mattress factory from Max Mogilner, a cousin. #417.'' On back of one photograph: ''Gregori (Harry) Mogilner, working in a Denver mattress factory, 1909. In 1925 moved to Colorado Springs & bought mattress factory from cousin Max Mogilner, #417.''
Gregori (Harry) Mogilner stitching a mattress in his factory during the early 20th century.

mets:mets.LABEL: Schachet Mercantile Company

mods:physicalDescription.mods:extent: 1 item (photograph), 5 x 4 inches, color
mods:physicalDescription.mods:note: Handwritten on envelope: ''#558 RMJHS Historic Denver Tour Roll II 6-27-82''. On back of photograph: ''6/27/82 II 16A-17 Schachet Mercantile''.

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Exterior view of the Schachet Mercantile Company on West Colfax Avenue in Denver, Colorado. The building was originally built as a saloon in 1896, rented by Eli Schachet and his sons in 1918 and served as the headquarters for their meat and fish store until it closed in 1981.

Exterior view of the Schachet Mercantile Company on West Colfax Avenue in Denver, Colorado. The building was originally built as a saloon in 1896, rented by Eli Schachet and his sons in 1918 and served as the headquarters for their meat and fish store until it closed in 1981.
Donated by Peryle Hayutin Beck.

mets:mets.LABEL: Star Bakery Delivery Wagon with Driver and Horses

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Star Bakery Delivery Wagon with Driver and Horses

mods:physicalDescription.mods:extent: 1 item (photograph), 4 x 5 inches, black and white
mods:physicalDescription.mods:note: Handwritten on envelope: "#200 Star Delivery Wagon." On back of photograph: "#200 Star Bakery Delivery Wagon, C. 1915, Donor Mrs. Sam Roscoe (Jeff-son) 377-4842."

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Two horses pull the Star Bakery delivery wagon and the driver leans out the side. The words ''Rye Bread'' and ''2744 W. Colfax'' appear on the side of the wagon with the Jewish star symbol. The Star Bakery was founded by Jacob Boscowitz and was later owned by his sons, Rudy and Sam Boscoe.

dc:dc.dc:title: Star Bakery Delivery Wagon with Driver and Horses
dc:dc.dc:format: 1 item (photograph), 4 x 5 inches, black and white
dc:dc.dc:description: Title supplied by archivist.
Appears in ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, page 40.
Handwritten on envelope: "#200 Star Delivery Wagon." On back of photograph: "#200 Star Bakery Delivery Wagon, C. 1915, Donor Mrs. Sam Roscoe (Jeff-son) 377-4842."

Two horses pull the Star Bakery delivery wagon and the driver leans out the side. The words ''Rye Bread'' and ''2744 W. Colfax'' appear on the side of the wagon with the Jewish star symbol. The Star Bakery was founded by Jacob Boscowitz and was later owned by his sons, Rudy and Sam Boscoe.
Donated by Mrs. Sam Boscoe (Jeff-son)

mets:mets.LABEL: Collage of Cook, Battock, and Hayutin Businesses

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Collage of Cook, Battock, and Hayutin Businesses

mods:physicalDescription.mods:extent: 1 item (photograph), 14 x 11 inches, black and white
mods:physicalDescription.mods:note: Handwritten on the back of the photograph: ''#57, Collage of Mrs. Harry Cook & Daughter of Cook's Baths. She was known as 'Dis Bakerkeh' in charge of the Mikveh.'; Mr. Harry Battock, peddler on fruit wagon; Motorcycle shop of Morris Hayutin; Donors: Mr. Louis Cook, Mrs. Mary Kreisman, Mr. Peryle H. Beck.''

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The upper left photograph shows Ida Cook and her daughter standing in front of a house. Harry and Ida Cook owned the Cook's Russian Baths in Denver, Colorado. At night, the Baths served as a mikveh (ritual bath) that was operated for women by Ida Cook. During the day the Baths served as a popular steam bath open to the public, complete with catered kosher meals. The upper right photograph shows Harry Battock, who came to Denver to be treated at the Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society, and peddled fruit and vegetables from a horse-drawn wagon on Denver's west side. The bottom photograph shows Morris Hayutin behind a motorcycle, underneath a canopy. There is another motorcycle beside Morris Hayutin and several cars are parked behind the canopy. Morris Hayutin's bicycle and motorcycle business, the Western Supply Company, was located on the corner of 15th and Larimer streets in Denver.
mods:mods.mods:note: Donated by Peryle Hayutin Beck, daughter of Morris Hayutin.
mods:mods.mods:accessCondition: Copyright restrictions may apply. User is responsible for all copyright compliance.

mets:mets.LABEL: Collage of Greeley Businesses

mods:physicalDescription.mods:extent: 1 item (photograph), 10 x 14 inches, black and white
mods:physicalDescription.mods:note: Handwritten on the back of the photograph: ''#56 Greeley Colorado Businesses; A. Winograd, Poultry; Samuel Pinsky, Coal, Hay and Feed; Montifiore J. Moses Real Estate and Insurance, In Creede, Later in Greeley, Donated by: Mrs. Eleanor Judd.''

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Three photographs of Greeley, Colorado businesses. The upper left photograph shows an exterior view of Abe Winograd's poultry business. Painted on the building is ''Poultry wanted at all times'' and pictures of a hen and a rooster. The photograph below shows an exterior view Samuel Pinsky's Coal, Hay, and Feed business. Samuel Pinsky is seated in the driver's seat of a wagon loaded with coal. Main photograph, two men sit in the interior of Montifiore J. Moses' Real Estate and Insurance Co. The business was originally in Creede, Colorado and then in Greeley, Colorado.

Handwritten on the back of the photograph: ''Cook's Baths Baseball Team, c.1912. Coach Sam Kantowitz [sic], Donated by Charlene Sachter, Mr. Louis Cook.'' Handwritten on the back of another copy of the photograph: ''#55, Cook's Baths' Baseball team, donor Louis Cook; 1. Al Fishman; 2. Dave Cook; 3. Harry Gibbons; 4. Max Sedalnick (Shep); 5. mods:mods.mods:abstract: Members of the 1912 Cook's Baths Baseball Team line up in front of a brick building. mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Billie Stein and Her Harmony Girls Band

mods:physicalDescription.mods:extent: 1 item (photograph), 8 x 10 inches, black and white
mods:physicalDescription.mods:note: Handwritten on back: ''#193 Billie on trumpet, Billie Stein on trumpet.'' On envelope: ''#193 Billie Stein's Orchestra, 1925.''

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Billie (Lillian) Stein poses with members of her Harmony Girls Orchestra. All five female members of the group are dressed in clown costumes with a ruff at the neck and with their instruments. Billie Stein is second from the right, holding her trumpet. Billie Stein started her own all-girls band at the age of 14 and traveled throughout the United States performing on her trumpet.
mods:mods.mods:note: Appears in ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, page 54.

mods:physicalDescription.mods:extent: 2 item (photograph), 6 x 8 inches, black and white
mods:physicalDescription.mods:note: Handwritten on back of photograph: ''1907 Sam Greenwald, Sam Golanty, ? Shachet, ? Stein, Sara Morris, Dora Gardenschwartz, Ida Cohen, Phil Francis, Izzie Greenwald, Louis Cook, Susie Sigman, Sarah Karsh; Cheltenham School, 8th Grade 1907, Principal Wm. Knapp, Teacher Miss Weymouth.'' Handwritten note with photograph: ''#21, 8th Grade Class of Cheltenham School, circa 1910, donated by Mr. Louis Cook; Some of the class: Principal Wm. Knapp, Teacher Miss Weymouth. Not in any order: Sam Greenwald, Sam Golanty, ? Shachet, ? Stein, Sara Morris, Dora Gardenschwartz, Si Mintz, Rod Goldberg, Ida Cohen, Phil Francis, Louis Cook, Sara Karsh, Rose Levy, Conrad Echstein, Lillian Neulander, Stella Webber, Susie Sigman, Izzie Greenwald.''

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The members of the 8th grade class at Cheltenham School sit on the steps of the school located at the corner of Irving Street and West Colfax Avenue in Denver, Colorado. Many of the Jewish children living in the West Colfax neighborhood went to Cheltenham School. The students include Sam Greenwald, Sam Golanty, ? Shachet, ? Stein, Sara Morris, Dora Gardenschwartz, Ida Cohen, Phil Francis, Izzie Greenwald, Louis Cook, Susie Sigman, Sarah Karsh, Si Mintz, Rod Goldberg, Rose Levy, Conrad Echstein, Lillian Neulander, Stella Webber as well as Principal William Knapp and teacher Miss Weymouth.
mods:mods.mods:note: Copy donated by Louis Cook, a student in the class.

mets:mets.LABEL: Advertisement for the Palm Theatre

mods:physicalDescription.mods:extent: 1 item (photograph), 10 x 8 inches, black and white
mods:physicalDescription.mods:note: On back of photograph: ''From Denver Jewish News, c. 1923.''

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Advertisement for the Yiddish theater at the Palm Theatre that appeared in the Denver Jewish News. The theater was located at 3116 West Colfax Avenue in Denver, Colorado. The main drama was ''The Second Wife'' on December 25, 1923. The Jewish Theatre was established by the Jewish Theatrical Company, organized by the Josephson family. The Jewish Theatrical Company operated from 1922 to 1926.
mods:mods.mods:note: Donated by the Denver Jewish News.
mods:mods.mods:accessCondition: Copyright restrictions may apply. User is responsible for all copyright compliance.

mets:mets.LABEL: Cripple Creek Jewish Community Members

mods:physicalDescription.mods:extent: 1 item (photograph), 5 x 7 inches, sepia
mods:physicalDescription.mods:note: On back of photograph: ''Sarah Sticker, Mrs. Gus Mautner, Mrs. L. Cohen, Mrs. Rosenberg, Mrs. Max Guldman, Clara Kolm, Dick Cohen, Paula Heller, Anna Segal, Regina Roth, Sadie Levy, May Garrett, Gertie Garrett, Mrs. L. Koretz, Sadie Schradsky, Nathan Segal, Ellis Rosenberg, Louis Koretz, Max Guldman, Morris Cohen, Harry Harris, Joe Cohen, Gus Mautner, Sol Segal, [illegible] Garrett, L. Silverman, L. Caro, S. Rudman; Return: Miriam Goldberg, 915 Monaco Pkwy, Denver, CO 80220; 861-2234; 377-0350; #990.'' On envelope: ''#990 Young Jewish Community of Cripple Creek, Co c. 1900.''

mods:mods.mods:abstract: A group of early Jewish residents of Cripple Creek, Colorado, gathered for a social outing in the 1890s. The following are pictured: Sarah Sticker, Mrs. Gus Mautner, Mrs. L. Cohen, Mrs. Rosenberg, Mrs. Max Guldman, Clara Kolm, Dick Cohen, Paula Heller, Anna Segal, Regina Roth, Sadie Levy, May Garrett, Gertie Garrett, Mrs. L. Koretz, Sadie Schradsky, Nathan Segal, Ellis Rosenberg, Louis Koretz, Max Guldman, Morris Cohen, Harry Harris, Joe Cohen, Gus Mautner, Sol Segal, H. Garrett, L. Silverman, L. Caro, and S. Rudman. Cripple Creek was a thriving mining town in the 1890s with an active Jewish community. Many Jewish merchants established themselves in Cripple Creek. Jewish religious services were held regularly, and a B'nai B'rith chapter was founded in 1901. After mining petered out in the area in the early years of the 20th century, most Jews moved to Denver.
mods:mods.mods:note: Appears in ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, page 114.
Photograph was donated by Miriam Goldberg.
mods:mods.mods:accessCondition: Copyright restrictions may apply. User is responsible for all copyright compliance.

mets:mets.LABEL: Home of Abraham Jacobs

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Title from back of photograph: __Home of A Jacobs, 16th Welton St.

mods:physicalDescription.mods:extent: 2 item (photograph), 6 x 4 inches, black and white
mods:physicalDescription.mods:note: On front of photograph, printed on the card portion: ''A.E. Rinehart, Denver, Colo.'' On back of photograph: ''A.E. Rinehart'' and: ''Duplicates can be had at any time'' in gold colored script, with gold colored logo: ''Larimer Street, 413 Denver, Col.'' Handwritten on the back: ''Home of A Jacobs, 16th Welton St., Before Masonic Temple was built there.''

mods:mods.mods:abstract: View of the exterior of the Abraham and Frances Wisebart Jacobs home at 16th Ave. and Welton St., Denver, Colo. View shows surrounding fence, with neighborhood homes, trees and streetcar lines visible in the background. Abraham Jacobs was a clothing merchant, his wife Frances was impetus behind founding of National Jewish Hospital.
mods:mods.mods:note: Appears in ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, on page 11.

Original owners were Abraham and Frances Wisebart Jacobs. The photograph was given to Jean Morris, their great-niece, who donated it to the Beck Archives in 1977. Related material may be found in the Frances Wisebart Jacobs Clothing and Other Material, B148.

mods:physicalDescription.mods:note: Inked on negative: ''Mile High Photo, 20135.'' Handwritten on envelope: ''#452 JCRS Misc. Medical Facilities.'' On back of photograph: ''#452 JCRS Major operating room for collapsing lungs.''

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Interior of the major operating room used for collapsed lungs on the campus of the Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society (JCRS). The JCRS was a sanatorium for tuberculosis patients that was founded in 1904 by a group of immigrant Jewish workingmen along with the support of several leading physicians and rabbis in Denver, Colorado. The sanatorium was located on West Colfax Avenue just outside of Denver.
mods:mods.mods:note: Accession # 1271, Donated by AMC Cancer Research Center as part of the JCRS Records.

mets:mets.LABEL: Seraphine Pisko

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Beck Archives Photograph Collection, Health Care and Philanthropy

mods:physicalDescription.mods:extent: 1 item (photograph), 5 x 7 inches, black and white
mods:physicalDescription.mods:note: Handwritten on envelope: ''#84 Mrs. Seraphine Pisko at NJH.'' On back of photograph: ''#84 Seraphine Pisko.''

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Seraphine Eppstein Pisko sits at a desk at National Jewish Hospital (NJH). She served as the president of the Hebrew Ladies' Benevolent Society (renamed the Jewish Relief Society in 1901) and as president of the Denver Council of Jewish Women. She also helped organize the Denver Jewish Settlement House and a free kindergarten to benefit the Eastern European Jewish immigrants on Denver's west side. Pisko became a fund-raiser for the National Jewish Hospital for Consumptives, and in 1911 she was appointed secretary of NJH and later was named executive director as well as vice president. She was in administrative control of the day-to-day activities until her retirement in 1938.
mods:mods.mods:note: Appears in ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, page 77.
mods:mods.mods:accessCondition: Copyright restrictions may apply. User is responsible for all copyright compliance.

Seraphine Eppstein Pisko sits at a desk at National Jewish Hospital (NJH). She served as the president of the Hebrew Ladies' Benevolent Society (renamed the Jewish Relief Society in 1901) and as president of the Denver Council of Jewish Women. She also helped organize the Denver Jewish Settlement House and a free kindergarten to benefit the Eastern European Jewish immigrants on Denver's west side. Pisko became a fund-raiser for the National Jewish Hospital for Consumptives, and in 1911 she was appointed secretary of NJH and later was named executive director as well as vice president. She was in administrative control of the day-to-day activities until her retirement in 1938.
Donated by National Jewish Hospital.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Fannie E. Lorber Breaking Ground at the Denver Sheltering Home for Jewish Children
Beck Archives Photograph Collection, Health Care and Philanthropy

mods:physicalDescription.mods:extent: 1 item (photograph), 5 x 7 inches, black and white
mods:physicalDescription.mods:note: Handwritten on envelope: ''#136 Fannie Lorber at Sheltering Home.'' On back of photograph: ''#136 Fannie Lorber Breaking Ground at the Sheltering Home 1937?''

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Mrs. Fannie E. Lorber was one of the founders of the Denver Sheltering Home, which opened in 1908. She is shoveling dirt for a groundbreaking of the Lorber Building, with many men and women looking on. The Sheltering Home began as a home for the children of tubercular patients who came to the sanitoriums in Denver, Colo.
mods:mods.mods:note: Appears in ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, page 88.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Art Class at the Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society
Beck Archives Photograph Collection, Health Care and Philanthropy

mods:physicalDescription.mods:extent: 1 item (photograph), 4 x 7 inches, black and white
mods:physicalDescription.mods:note: Handwritten on envelope: ''#462 JCRS Patient Activities''. On back of photograph: ''#462 JCRS Art Class - 1942''.

mods:mods.mods:abstract: An art class that is part of the rehabilitation program of the Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society (JCRS) meets for a session. Male patients sit on folding chairs in a half circle around a male model wearing a robe, pajamas, slippers and hat. Max Lazarus, a German-Jewish artist, is pictured second from the left. Twenty-three charcoal drawings hang on the walls. The JCRS was a sanatorium for tuberculosis patients that was founded in 1904 by a group of immigrant Jewish workingmen along with the support of several leading physicians and rabbis in Denver, Colorado. It was located on West Colfax Avenue just outside of Denver.
mods:mods.mods:note: Donated by AMC Cancer Research Center (JCRS).

mets:mets.LABEL: Geriatric Center at Beth Israel Hospital

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Geriatric Center at Beth Israel Hospital
Beck Archives Photograph Collection, Health Care and Philanthropy

mods:physicalDescription.mods:extent: 1 item (photograph), 5 x 7 inches, black and white
mods:physicalDescription.mods:note: Handwritten on envelope: ''#543 Beth Israel Home.'' On back of photograph: ''#543 Old Folks Home Beth Israel Hospital.''

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Exterior view of the Geriatric Center at Beth Israel Hospital in Denver, Colorado at the corner of Sixteenth Avenue and Lowell Boulevard. Beth Israel opened in Denver's west-side community in 1920 as a Jewish old-age home. It added a Jewish-run general hospital in 1923. Sparked by Bella Mintz, it garnered the support of members of Denver's Jewish community from throughout the city. Philanthropists Leopold Guldman, Isadore Rude, and Adolph Kiesler provided especially generous donations. Eventually its geriatric center evolved into Denver's Shalom Park, located today in Aurora, Colorado.
mods:mods.mods:note: Appears in ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, page 90.
Donated by Beth Israel Hospital and Geriatric Center.

mods:name.mods:namePart: Beth Israel Home for the Aged (Denver, Colo.)
Beth Israel Hospital and Home Society (Denver, Colo.)

Sparked by Bella Mintz, it garnered the support of members of Denver's Jewish community from throughout the city. mets:mets.LABEL: Founders of the Denver Sheltering Home for Jewish Children

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Founders of the Denver Sheltering Home for Jewish Children
Beck Archives Photograph Collection, Health Care and Philanthropy

mods:physicalDescription.mods:extent: 1 item (notecard), 5 x 7 inches, sepia
mods:physicalDescription.mods:note: Handwritten on envelope: ''#1134 Founders of Denver Sheltering Home c 1907 (Fannie Lorber, Bessie Willen, etc.)''. The women are identified on the back of a National Jewish Medical and Research Center note card as, from left to right, Jennie Kantrowitz, Mollie Lifshutz, Bessie Willens, Mary Augenblich, Fannie Lorber, and Mrs. S. Disraelly. [The last woman is misidentified as S. Disraelly and should be Sadie Francis.]

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Promotional note card from National Jewish Medical and Research Center showing the founders of the Denver Sheltering Home for Jewish Children. From left to right are Jennie Kantrowitz, Mollie Lifshutz, Bessie Willens, Mary Augenblich, Fannie Lorber and Sadie Francis. The Denver Sheltering Home for Jewish Children was founded in 1907 to care for children whose parents were victims of tuberculosis. It later evolved into the National Home for Asthmatic Children and eventually merged with National Jewish Hospital. Spearheaded by Fannie Lorber and Bessie Willens and other immigrant East European Jewish women, the home provided a traditional Jewish environment for the children who passed through its doors, as well as a strong secular education.
mods:mods.mods:note: Appears in ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, page 87.
Created by National Jewish Hospital as part of their Centennial Celebration.

mods:name.mods:namePart: Denver Sheltering Home for Jewish Children

mets:mets.LABEL: Patients Undergoing Heliotherapy at the Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Patients Undergoing Heliotherapy at the Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society
Beck Archives Photograph Collection, Health Care and Philanthropy

mods:physicalDescription.mods:extent: 1 item (photograph), 4 x 6 inches, black and white
mods:physicalDescription.mods:note: On envelope: ''#462 JCRS Patient Activities.'' On back of photograph: ''JCRS TB Patients undergoing Heliotherapy, 1920s.''

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Unidentified tuberculosis patients undergoing heliotherapy at the Main Medical Building of the Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society (JCRS). Fresh air and sunshine were popular treatments for tuberculosis and patients were encouraged to spend time outside. The JCRS was a sanatorium for tuberculosis patients that was founded in 1904 by a group of immigrant Jewish workingmen along with the support of several leading physicians and rabbis in Denver, Colorado. The sanatorium was located on West Colfax Avenue just outside of Denver.
mods:mods.mods:note: Appears in ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, page 83.
Accession # 1271, Donated by AMC Cancer Research Center as part of the JCRS Records.

mets:mets.LABEL: Texas Pavilion Building at the Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Texas Pavilion Building at the Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society
Beck Archives Photograph Collection, Health Care and Philanthropy

mods:physicalDescription.mods:extent: 1 item (photograph), 4 x 5 inches, black and white
mods:physicalDescription.mods:note: Handwritten on envelope: ''#180 JCRS Group of pictures''. On back of photograph: ''#180 JCRS Texas Building now the cancer hospital''.

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The Texas Pavilion for Women Building on the campus of the Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society (JCRS) opened in 1927. The JCRS was a sanatorium for tuberculosis patients that was founded in 1904 by a group of immigrant Jewish working men along with the support of several leading physicians and rabbis in Denver, Colorado. It was located on West Colfax Avenue just outside of Denver. As of 2009, the Texas Pavilion was being used as part of the Rocky Mountain College of Art and Design.

mets:mets.LABEL: Adolph Kiesler at Cornerstone Ceremony for Beth Israel Home

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Adolph Kiesler at Cornerstone Ceremony for Beth Israel Home
Beck Archives Photograph Collection, Health Care and Philanthropy

mods:physicalDescription.mods:extent: 1 item (photograph), 11 x 14 inches, black and white
mods:physicalDescription.mods:note: Handwritten on back of photograph: ''laying the cornerstone of Beth Israel Hospital, Adolph Kiesler, 1940.''

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Adolph Kiesler attends a cornerstone ceremony for Beth Israel Home for the Aged at West 16th Avenue and Lowell Boulevard, Denver, Colorado. He stands in a suit and holds his hat in his left arm while shaking hands with a man in a suit and overcoat. Two men in suits, hats and overcoats stand behind Adolph Kiesler. Two men in work clothes stand behind the cornerstone that is attached to a pulley. ''Home for the Aged 1940 Erected 5700'' is chiseled on the stone. A boy stands, and two boys (one wears a jacket, the others are in shirtsleeves) sit on a brick wall.
mods:mods.mods:note: Donated by Peggy Lehmann, granddaughter of Adolph Kiesler.

mets:mets.LABEL: Exterior of the first National Jewish Hospital building (The Frances Jacobs Hospital)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Exterior of the first National Jewish Hospital building (The Frances Jacobs Hospital)
Beck Archives Photograph Collection, Health Care and Philanthropy

mods:physicalDescription.mods:extent: 1 item (photograph), 8 x 10 inches, black and white
mods:physicalDescription.mods:note: On back of photograph: ''#1116 First NJH Building, 1899 pg. 30''. On envelope: ''#1116 National Jewish Hospital - Misc. Historic Photos Patient Days of Care By State, 1949''.

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Exterior shot features a sign over the top front porch, which reads, "The Frances Jacobs Hospital". The name was changed to National Jewish Hospital in 1899. Two men (unidentified) stand in front of the building. In 1907, the name of the hospital changed to the National Asthma Center. It later became the Children's Asthma Research Institute and Hospital, National Jewish Hospital/National Asthma Center (1978), and National Jewish Center for Immunology and Respiratory Medicine (1985).
mods:mods.mods:note: Appears in ''Images of America, Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, page 76.
Donated by the National Jewish Hospital.

mets:mets.LABEL: Children in Front of the Jewish Sheltering Home in Denver

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Children in Front of the Jewish Sheltering Home in Denver
Beck Archives Photograph Collection, Health Care and Philanthropy

mods:physicalDescription.mods:extent: 1 item (photograph), 8 x 11 inches, black and white

mods:mods.mods:abstract: A group of children gather in front of the original Denver Sheltering Home at 19th Street and Julian Street in Denver, Colorado. A man and the matron stand on either side of the children. The Sheltering Home began as a home for the children of tuberculosis patients who came to the sanatoriums in Denver. The Denver Sheltering Home later became the National Asthma Center. The original building was destroyed by fire in 1914. The 36 children living in the home at the time were taken in by neighborhood families until a new building could be erected.
mods:mods.mods:note: Donated by AMC Cancer Research Center (JCRS).

mets:mets.LABEL: Dr. Charles Spivak at His Desk With Dictaphone

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Dr. Charles Spivak at His Desk With Dictaphone
Beck Archives Photograph Collection, Health Care and Philanthropy

mods:physicalDescription.mods:extent: 1 item (photograph), 8 x 10 inches, black and white
mods:physicalDescription.mods:note: On back of photograph: ''Dr. Charles Spivak #1124.''

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Dr. Charles Spivak sits at his desk and speaks into a dictaphone. Dr. Spivak was a founder of the Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society (JCRS). The JCRS was a sanatorium for tuberculosis patients that was founded in 1904 by a group of immigrant Jewish workingmen along with the support of several leading physicians and rabbis in Denver, Colorado. The sanatorium was located on West Colfax Avenue just outside of Denver.
mods:mods.mods:note: Donated by AMC Cancer Research Center (JCRS).

mets:mets.LABEL: National Council of Jewish Women, Denver Section, Kosher Picnic at Leadville, Colorado

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: National Council of Jewish Women, Denver Section, Kosher Picnic at Leadville, Colorado

mods:physicalDescription.mods:extent: 1 item (photograph), 8 x 10 inches, black and white
mods:physicalDescription.mods:note: On front of photograph: ''To the Council of Jewish Women, Denver, Colo. Compliments of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred A. Freedheim. Jewish Picnic given at Leadville, Colo. complimenting Miss Sadie American touring the U.S. organizing the Councils of Jewish Women, July 28, 1895.'' ''See Row'' is inked on front of photograph. Handwritten on the back of the photograph: ''Souvenir of a Gala day at Twin Lakes, July 28-95. Standing Mrs. Saidi Lands, x, Dr. Sol G. Kahn, Mr. Sol Garrett, x, Martha Kafiski, Mrs. Adolph Bair, Miss Sadie American, Mrs. Carrie Mayer, Alfred A. Freedham, Grace Diamond. In Bus: Bus Driver, Mr. Ben Brown, Amelia Friedlander, x, Alfred Huffman, x, Tillie Kahn, Mother of Sadie American, x, Son of Mrs. Adolph Bair, Mr. Rosenbush, x.'' ''x Deceased.'' Typed on paper attached to the back of the photograph: Contact: Janice Rosen 721-6766. Caption for Photo Accompanying Attached Article for Release June 3, 1988. In 1895 the young organization set out to attract attention to their organization and increase membership. Denver Section hosted a visit from Miss Sadie American who was touring the country to help form new sections. Trips into the mining communities of Colorado were arranged. This picture was taken on an excursion to Leadville.''

mods:mods.mods:abstract: A group of men and women in and in front of a horse drawn wagon. Standing in front of the wagon left to right: Mrs. Saidi Lands, Dr. Sol G. Kahn, Sol Garrett, Martha Kafiski, Mrs. Adolph Bair, Miss Sadie American, Mrs. Carrie Mayer, Alfred A. Freedham, and Grace Diamond. On the wagon: unidentified man, Ben Brown (driver), Amelia Friedlander (holding sign), Alfred Huffman, Tillie Kahn, the Mother of Sadie American, the Son of Mrs. Adolph Bair, and Mr. Rosenbush. The group participates in a Jewish picnic at Twin Lakes in Leadville, Colorado. Amelia Freedlander holds a sign that reads, ''This Way Kosher Picnic.'' The word ''Kosher'' is in Hebrew. The Denver Section of the National Council of Jewish Women (NCJW) hosted the picnic to honor Sadie American who was touring the country to help form new sections of NCJW. The Denver Section was founded in 1893, the same year the national organization was established to promote Jewish education, philanthropy, and social reform. The early group of women worked to offer aid and to Americanize East European immigrants at the turn of the 20th Century.
mods:mods.mods:note: Appears in ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, page 74.

Given to the National Council of Jewish Women by Mr. and Mrs. Arthur A. Friedheim. Arthur A. Friedheim is one of the people in the photograph. National Council of Jewish Women, Denver Section donated it to Beck Archives in December 1976.

mets:mets.LABEL: Ben Glass with H. Leivick, Yiddish Poet

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Ben Glass with H. Leivick, Yiddish Poet
Beck Archives Photograph Collection, Families and Groups

mods:physicalDescription.mods:extent: 1 item (photograph), 5 x 7.5 inches, black and white
mods:physicalDescription.mods:note: On front of matting: ''Cavarra Studio, Denver'' and handwritten Yiddish words and ''1933.'' Handwritten on back of photograph: ''Ben Glass with H. Leivick, Yiddish poet, 1933. Patients of JCRS. Donor: Mr. and Mrs. Ben Glass.

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Portrait of Ben Glass (at left) and H. Leivick (the pen name of Leyvik Halpern or Leivick Halper), Yiddish poet. Both men were patients at the Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society (JCRS). Ben Glass was a printer at the JCRS bindery from 1928 to 1978 when it closed. The JCRS was a sanatorium for tuberculosis patients that was founded in 1904 by a group of immigrant Jewish working men along with the support of several leading physicians and rabbis in Denver, Colorado. It was located on West Colfax Avenue just outside of Denver. This is a copy of the original photograph and matting.
mods:mods.mods:note: Photograph dimensions include matting shown in photograph.
Donated by Ben and Bessie Glass.

mets:mets.LABEL: Portrait of the Louis Anfenger Family

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Portrait of the Louis Anfenger Family
Beck Archives Photograph Collection, Families and Groups

mods:physicalDescription.mods:extent: 1 item (photograph), 8 x 10 inches, black and white
mods:physicalDescription.mods:note: On back of photograph: ''#37 Family of Louis Anfenger Donor Marjorie Hornbein''. On envelope: ''#37 Louis Anfenger and Louis Anfenger family, c 1890s''.

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Louis (1842-1900) and Louise Schlesinger (1847-1938) Anfenger seated front center, with their eight children. Children, back row, left to right: Max, Fannie, Stella, Milton, and Fred. Children front row: Harold, Flora, and Joseph. Louis Anfenger was born in Bavaria and came to the United States in the 1850s. He moved west to Denver, Colorado in 1870, started out working as a clerk, and became a highly successful businessman in the area of real estate. Louise He was also elected to the state legislature in the 1880s. Anfenger built a stately house at Champa Street and Twenty-Ninth Street for his wife Louise and their large family.
mods:mods.mods:note: Appears in ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, on page 20.

mets:mets.LABEL: Montage of Elias Cohen and Family of Aspen, Colorado

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Montage of Elias Cohen and Family of Aspen, Colorado
Beck Archives Photograph Collection, Families and Groups

mods:physicalDescription.mods:extent: 1 item (photograph), 10 x 8 inches, black and white
mods:physicalDescription.mods:note: On envelope: ''Elias Cohen family of Aspen, 1905''. Note inside envelope: ''#52 Elias Cohen family - supervisor of mines in Aspen in Aspen, with his wife and children and his wife's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Charles Weinberg Aspen 1905 (Mrs. Elias Cohen, nee Weinberg) donated by Mrs. Regina Collins''.

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Collage of the Elias Cohen family of Aspen including a formal portrait of Elias Cohen (bottom left); a formal portrait of his wife and two daughters (bottom right); and formal portraits of his in-laws, Mr. and Mrs. Charles Weinberg (top). Elias Cohen was a resident of Aspen by 1891, a mine supervisor in, and manager of David Hyman's properties. It was Cohen who suggested the use of deep-sea divers to repair broken mine-pump shafts.
mods:mods.mods:note: Appears in ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, on page 120.
mods:mods.mods:accessCondition: Copyright restrictions may apply. User is responsible for all copyright compliance.

mods:physicalDescription.mods:extent: 1 item (photograph), 10 x 8 inches, black and white
mods:physicalDescription.mods:note: ''Morris Hayutin Family at Manitou Springs, c. 1914.''

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Morris and Anna (Ginsberg) Hayutin siting in the front seat in the car, Soloman Hayutin is the other man in the car, and Devera and Max Ginsberg sit on the back seat. The car is parked in front of the Balanced Rock in Garden of the Gods, Colorado Springs, Colorado. Morris Hayutin's niece, Freda Hayutin (child) is also seated in the car. Members of the Hayutin family arrived in Denver in the 1890s.

mods:physicalDescription.mods:note: On envelope: ''#78 Sunshine, Feiner and Ginsberg Families Immigrants''. On note inside envelope: ''#78 Immigrants: Mr. and Mrs. Sunshine Donor: Mrs. Albert Brennan Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Feiner Donor: Mr. Louis Cook Mr. and MRs. Jacob Sarnoff Ginsberg. He made 6 crossings to Russia and died in Brest-Letovsk, 1914 Donor: Mrs. Ira Beck''.

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Three formal poses of the heads of the Sunshine, Feiner, and Ginsberg families: Mr. and Mrs. Sunshine (left, standing), Mr.and Mrs. Jacob Feiner (center, seated and wearing hats), Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Sarnoff Ginsberg (right, she is standing, he is seated). Composite was made sometime in the 1970s, but the original images date to the early 20th century.
mods:mods.mods:note: Appears in ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, on page 94.
Donated by Mrs. Albert Brenman, Mr. Louis cook and Mrs. Ira Beck.

mods:physicalDescription.mods:note: On envelope: ''Hayutin Children, 1924, Irving age 6, Arthur age 3.''

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Irving (age 6) and Arthur (age 3) Hayutin sit together in a small cart drawn by a goat in front of their childhood home on Denver's west side. mets:mets.LABEL: Jacob and Charlotte Gordon and their Daughters

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Jacob and Charlotte Gordon and their Daughters
Beck Archives Photograph Collection, Families and Groups

mods:physicalDescription.mods:extent: 1 item (photograph), 7 x 5 inches, black and white

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Jacob and Charlotte Gordon stand in front of a building. In front of them are their daughters, Bess (with a large bow), Baila, and Eleanor. A son born later is not shown in the photograph. Jacob, a schohet (a kosher slaughterer in the Jewish tradition), Talmudic scholar, and later a mohel (one who performs the ritual circumcision), migrated to Denver, Colorado, in 1914 from Russia to join his uncle, Velvel Heller. By 1917 Jacob Gordon saved enough to bring his wife and daughter Bess from Russia and the family settled on Denver's west side. Two more daughters and a son were born in Denver. Charlotte Gordon was a founder of the Beth David Sisterhood, which was organized for the purpose of building a school for Jewish education on Denver's west side. As treasurer she collected dimes and quarters for the school in the neighborhoods on the west side of Denver. The Sisterhood merged with the Denver Hebrew Institute and became the Hebrew Educational Alliance.
mods:mods.mods:note: Appears in ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, page 106.
A copy was donated for an article by Marjorie Hornbein in the Rocky Mountain Jewish Historical Notes, Volume 4, Number 3, Spring 1982.
mods:mods.mods:accessCondition: Copyright restrictions may apply. User is responsible for all copyright compliance.

Jacob, a schohet (a kosher slaughterer in the Jewish tradition), Talmudic scholar, and later a mohel (one who performs the ritual circumcision), migrated to Denver, Colorado, in 1914 from Russia to join his uncle, Velvel Heller. By 1917 Jacob Gordon saved enough to bring his wife and daughter Bess from Russia and the family settled on Denver's west side. Two more daughters and a son were born in Denver. Charlotte Gordon was a founder of the Beth David Sisterhood, which was organized for the purpose of building a school for Jewish education on Denver's west side. As treasurer she collected dimes and quarters for the school in the neighborhoods on the west side of Denver. The Sisterhood merged with the Denver Hebrew Institute and became the Hebrew Educational Alliance.
A copy was donated for an article by Marjorie Hornbein in the Rocky Mountain Jewish Historical Notes, Volume 4, Number 3, Spring 1982.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Bernstein Family at Seven Falls, Colorado
Beck Archives Photograph Collection, Families and Groups

mods:physicalDescription.mods:extent: 1 item (photograph), 3 x 5 inches, black and white
mods:physicalDescription.mods:note: Postcard markings stamped on back of photograph. Handwritten on back of photograph: ''Seven Falls, Colo. June 1910, Family of Moritz Bernstein of Walsenberg [sic], Donor Morton P. Stark.'' On envelope: ''Bernstein family of Walsenberg[sic] at Seven Falls, 1910.''

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Mrs. Moritz Bernstein, her son and daughter and an unidentified woman ride on burros in front of the waterfalls at Seven Falls, Colorado Springs, Colorado, during a tour. Mrs. Bernstein's other son stands behind the group beside a fake elk. All five of the men and women are wearing hats. Moritz Bernstein had a dry goods store in Walsenburg, Colorado, where the family lived and in other southern Colorado towns.
mods:mods.mods:note: Appears in ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, on page 125.

mods:physicalDescription.mods:note: On back of photograph: ''Philip and Flora (Anfenger) Hornbein Philip Jr. and Marjorie, 1923 California trip.''

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Flora and Philip Hornbein stand in front of a false scenic coastline backdrop with their children, Marjorie and Philip Jr., mounted on a cardboard donkey in front of them. Photograph was taken on a trip to San Francisco, California in 1923. Philip Hornbein was a Colorado trial lawyer, a leader in the fight against the Ku Klux Klan, and chairman of Colorado's Democratic Party during the presidency of Franklin D. Roosevelt.
mods:mods.mods:note: Appears in ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, page 23.

mets:mets.LABEL: Shwayder Family

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Beck Archives Photograph Collection, Families and Groups

mods:physicalDescription.mods:extent: 1 item (photograph), 6 x 7 inches, black and white
mods:physicalDescription.mods:note: Caption from photo book: ''The Shwayder Family celebrating the 80th birthday of Rachel Shwayder, seated center, at the Green Gables country Club, Denver, c. 1950. In 1910 Jesse Shwayder opened a small luggage factroy and with his brothers, Mark, Maurice, Benjamin, and Solomon, turned it into one of the largest luggage producers in America, the Samsonite Corporation. Leaders in Denver philanthropy, the Shwayder family took an especially active role in Rose Hospital, the University of Denver, the Denver Art Museum, the National Jewish Hospital, Temple Emanuel, and many other organizations. Courtesy: Mr. and Mrs. King Shwayder, Sponsor: Mr. and Mrs. King Shwayder.''

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The Shwayder family pose on a stairway at the Green Gables Country Club during Rachel Shwayder's 80th birthday celebration.

Beck Archives Photograph Collection, Families and Groups

mods:physicalDescription.mods:extent: 1 item (photograph), 4 x 3 inches, black and white

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Full-length portrait of Israel Kortz in his suit and bowler hat and Rebecca Kortz in a dress and hat. She holds a parasol. The Kortz family originated in Brest Litovsk, Russia, and arrived in Denver, Colorado around 1885. The Kortz family and their descendants contributed to the development of Denver and its Jewish community.

Beck Archives Photograph Collection, Families and Groups

mods:physicalDescription.mods:extent: 1 item (photograph), 9.5 x 8 inches, black and white

mets:mets.LABEL: William Goldblatt and Family

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Beck Archives Photograph Collection, Families and Groups

mods:physicalDescription.mods:extent: 1 item (photograph), 5 x 7 inches, black and white
mods:physicalDescription.mods:note: Handwritten on back of photograph: ''Denver Newton St. 1914, William and Helen Goldblatt, Ruth and Marvin Goldblatt children.''

mods:mods.mods:abstract: William Goldblatt and his family stand on the porch of their home at 1473 Newton Street in Denver, Colorado. Goldblatt followed an unusual profession for a Denver Jewish citizen when he became a local fireman. Later, he became a Denver police officer and wore badge number one. He is pictured here in police uniform with his wife, Helen, and children Ruth and Marvin.
mods:mods.mods:note: This is a copy of the original photograph.
Appears in ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, page 45.

mets:mets.LABEL: Rabbi Manuel Laderman at Union Station

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Rabbi Manuel Laderman at Union Station
Beck Archives Photograph Collection, Religious Life

mods:physicalDescription.mods:extent: 1 item (photograph), 5 x 8.5 inches, black and white

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Twenty-three-year-old Rabbi Manuel Laderman (tallest man in the group) surrounded by delegates from the Hebrew Educational Alliance upon his arrival at Union Station, Denver, Colorado in 1932. He graduated from the Hebrew Theological College in Illinois and had just been ordained when he came to Denver to serve as the first Rabbi of the Hebrew Educational Alliance. He served as rabbi at the Orthodox synagogue until 1979. He was born August 25, 1909 and died in Denver on November 27, 1989.
mods:mods.mods:note: Copy of photograph is missing and a reprint was made.
Appears in ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, page 68.
Copy of the photograph was donated for the Rocky Mountain Jewish Historical Society Annual Meeting in 2000.
mods:mods.mods:accessCondition: Copyright restrictions may apply. User is responsible for all copyright compliance.

He graduated from the Hebrew Theological College in Illinois and had just been ordained when he came to Denver to serve as the first Rabbi of the Hebrew Educational Alliance. He served as rabbi at the Orthodox synagogue until 1979. He was born August 25, 1909 and died in Denver on November 27, 1989.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Exterior View of Yad Achass (Rumanian Shul)
Beck Archives Photograph Collection, Religious Life

mods:physicalDescription.mods:extent: 1 item (photograph), 5 x 7 inches, black and white
mods:physicalDescription.mods:note: Handwritten on back of photograph: ''Rumansche Shul, Photograph by Charles McNamara, 1979.''

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Many small synagogues, or shuls, were built in Denver, Colorado's west-side with the East European immigrant Jewish community, including Yad Achass, more commonly known as the Rumansche (Romanian) shul. It was orgainized in 1903, and its second home, pictured here, was at the corner of King Street and Conejos Place.
mods:mods.mods:note: Appears in ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, page 66.
The photograph donated by the photographer, Charles McNamara.

mets:mets.LABEL: Rabbi Elias Hillkowitz

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Beck Archives Photograph Collection, Religious Life

mods:physicalDescription.mods:extent: 1 item (photograph), 7 x 5 inches, black and white
mods:physicalDescription.mods:note: On back of photograph: ''Rabbi Elias Hillkowitz.''

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Rabbi Elias Hillkowitz was considered the dean of Denver's early west-side Orthodox Jewish rabbis. He was an early supporter of the Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society (JCRS), where his son, Dr. Philip Hillkowitz, served as president from 1904 to 1948. Rabbi Hillkowitz suggested the JCRS motto from the Talmud: ''He who saves one life saves the world.''
mods:mods.mods:note: Appears in ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, page 67.
Photograph from JCRS publication, The Sanatorium.
mods:mods.mods:accessCondition: Copyright restrictions may apply. User is responsible for all copyright compliance.

mets:mets.LABEL: Exterior View of Congregation Zera Abraham

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Exterior View of Congregation Zera Abraham
Beck Archives Photograph Collection, Religious Life

mods:physicalDescription.mods:extent: 1 item (photograph), 5 x 7 inches, black and white

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Congregation Zera Abraham was originally organized as a Chassidic Orthodox Jewish congregation in 1877, making it the oldest congregation on the west side of Denver, Colorado. The building shown here at Julian Street and West Conejos Place was the congregation's second home. It was purchased in 1938 from the Workmen's Circle, which originally erected the building as the Labor Lyceum, an educational center. The congregation moved to its third location on Winona Court.
mods:mods.mods:note: Appears in ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, page 64.
Donated by the photographer, Charles McNamara
mods:mods.mods:accessCondition: Copyright restrictions may apply. User is responsible for all copyright compliance.

mets:mets.LABEL: Exterior of Hebrew Education Alliance

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Beck Archives Photograph Collection, Religious Life

mods:physicalDescription.mods:extent: 1 item (photograph), 5 x 7 inches, black and white

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The Hebrew Educational Alliance's original building at West Colfax and Meade Street. It was founded in 1932 and became the largest congregation on Denver's west side. The Hebrew Educational Alliance was created as a result of the ''alliance'' between the Beth David Hebrew School Sisterhood and Brotherhood, and the Denver Hebrew Institute. On October 25, 1932, Rabbi Manuel Laderman arrived in Denver to serve as the first Rabbi of the Hebrew Educational Alliance. The combined synagogue and Hebrew School was organized along Orthodox lines. When the Alliance moved into another building, the original building became the Golden West Nursing Home.
mods:mods.mods:note: Photograph was mislaid and was replaced by another print.
Appears in ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, page 68.
Donated by the photographer, Dr. Charles Mcnamara.
mods:mods.mods:accessCondition: Copyright restrictions may apply. User is responsible for all copyright compliance.

mets:mets.LABEL: Portrait of Philip Hornbein Reading

mods:physicalDescription.mods:extent: 1 item (photograph), 8 x 10 inches, black and white
mods:physicalDescription.mods:note: On back of photograph: ''#135 Marjorie Hornbein 1124 Steele Denver, CO 80206 1938 Philip Hornbein Donated by Miss Marjorie Hornbein''. On envelope: ''#135 Phillip Hornbein, 1938''.

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Philip Hornbein is reading in a chair with a cigarette in his hand. Hornbein was one of Colorado's top trial lawyers, a leader in the fight against the Ku Klux Klan, and chairman of Colorado's Democratic Party during the presidency of Franklin D. Roosevelt. He graduated from the University of Denver School of Law, practiced in Cripple Creek, then Denver, Colorado.
mods:mods.mods:note: Framed copy of this photograph in collection B167.
Appears in ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, on page 22.
mods:mods.mods:accessCondition: Copyright restrictions may apply. User is responsible for all copyright compliance.

mods:physicalDescription.mods:note: Handwritten on back of photograph: ''E. Grimes.''

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Ed Grimes in a formal portrait taken for the Independent Order of B'nai B'rith Lodge #171 in Denver, Colorado. Ed Grimes was a colonist at Cotopaxi, Colorado and walked to Denver from Cotopaxi in 1883, a distance of about 94 miles. He later served as Congregation Zera Abraham's first president and was also active in B'nai B'rith Lodge #171.

mets:mets.LABEL: Shul Baer Milstein Sits with a Long Pipe

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Shul Baer Milstein Sits with a Long Pipe

mods:physicalDescription.mods:extent: 1 item (photograph), 5.5 x 4 inches, black and white
mods:physicalDescription.mods:note: Handwritten on back of photograph: ''Shul Baer Milstein, 1880s.''

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Shul Baer Milstein, wearing a yarmulka and smoking a long pipe, sits at a table with an open Talmud in front of him. A tapestry hangs on the wall behind his chair. Milstein, who immigrated from Russia, was an early leader in Denver's west side Orthodox Jewish community and in Congregation Zera Abraham. He was also a patriarch of the Cotopaxi Colony, an agricultural community located in Cotopaxi, Colorado that failed in 1884. He was a peddler and later opened his own kosher butcher shop.
mods:mods.mods:note: Appears in ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, on page 65.
mods:mods.mods:accessCondition: Copyright restrictions may apply. User is responsible for all copyright compliance.

mets:mets.LABEL: Clara Goldsmith Stands in Formal Pose

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Clara Goldsmith Stands in Formal Pose

mods:physicalDescription.mods:extent: 1 item (photograph), 7 x 5 inches, black and white
mods:physicalDescription.mods:note: Handwritten on envelope: ''Goldsmith, Clara (Weil) (sic), born Denver 1860.''

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Clara Goldsmith Weil stands behind a fence prop for a formal portrait. Clara, born in 1860, was the first female Jewish baby born in Denver. Clara's parents, Clara and Henry Goldsmith, had migrated by covered wagon from Leavenworth, Kansas. The elder Clara died in childbirth and her daugher was named after her mother. Clara Goldsmith Weil was raised by her aunt and uncle Rosa and Abraham Goldsmith. The elder Clara Goldsmith's death was the impetus behind the organization of Denver's first Jewish burial society.
mods:mods.mods:note: Appears in ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, page 15.
mods:mods.mods:accessCondition: Copyright restrictions may apply. User is responsible for all copyright compliance.

mods:physicalDescription.mods:extent: 1 item (photograph), 7 x 5 inches, Black and white
mods:physicalDescription.mods:note: Handwritten on back of photograph: ''Hannah Levy as a young woman.''

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Hannah Levy sits in an outdoor setting in the early 1930s. Hannah and brother Jack Levy are the founders of several women's clothing retail stores, in Colorado: the Hosiery Bar, Fashion Bar, and Hannah. She also became a leading Colorado philanthropist and helped support numerous community institutions, including the Rose Hospital and the University of Denver.

mets:mets.LABEL: Ray David

mods:physicalDescription.mods:extent: 1 item (photograph), 7 x 5 inches, Black and white

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Ray S. David stands in an outdoor setting in a suit and hat. In 1915, Mrs. Ray S. David was hired as superintendent of the Denver's Jewish Aid Society to supervise relief activities. She was nicknamed ''Little Mother to the Poor'' for her settlement work with East European Jewish immigrants. Ray David was a member of the Woman's Club of Denver, Denver Board of Charities and Corrections as well as the State Board of Pardons, and campaigned for women's suffrage.
mods:mods.mods:note: Appears in ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, page 74.
Copy donated by Ray David's granddaughter Bobbie Meyer.

mets:mets.LABEL: Channah Milstein Wearing a Kerchief

mods:physicalDescription.mods:extent: 1 item (photograph), 5 x 4 inches, black and white
mods:physicalDescription.mods:note: Handwritten on back of photograph: ''Channah Milstein, grandmother? of Phil Milstein, member 'Glazierlach' clan of west-side Denver, Cotopaxi colonist, donor Mrs. Sylvan Moses.''

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Head and shoulders portrait of Mrs. Channah Milstein wearing a traditional kerchief or tichel headcovering. She was a member of the Jewish "Glazierlach" clan and a Cotopaxi colonist before moving to Denver's west side Orthodox Jewish Community. Channah Milstein was known for her personal commitment to charity in Denver's west-side East European immigrant Jewish community as she urged residents to contribute to her collections of food, clothing, and money for the needy.
mods:mods.mods:note: Appears in ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, on page 75.
Donated by Mrs. Sylvan Moses who retained the original.

mets:mets.LABEL: Portrait of Anna Ginsberg Hayutin

mods:physicalDescription.mods:extent: 1 item (photograph), 5 x 4 inches., black and white
mods:physicalDescription.mods:note: On back of photograph: ''#465 Anna F. Hayutin 1912? (Mrs. Morris Hayutin)''. On envelope: ''#465 Hayutin Family''.

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Anna Ginsberg Hayutin sits with her hands folded on her lap. She wears an elaborate hat and a long dress with lace at the collar and sleeves. Anna Ginsberg was born in Russia but came to New York City with her parents, D'vera and Max Ginsberg. They moved to Denver in 1910 when she was still a young girl. Anna married the son of Russian immigrants, businessman Morris Hayutin, who owned the Western Supply Company and later the Public Industrial Bank.
mods:mods.mods:note: Pictured in ''Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, page 99.

dc:dc.dc:title: Portrait of Anna Ginsberg Hayutin
dc:dc.dc:format: 1 item (photograph), 5 x 4 inches., black and white
dc:dc.dc:description: Title supplied by archivist.
Pictured in ''Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, page 99.
On back of photograph: ''#465 Anna F. Hayutin 1912? (Mrs. Morris Hayutin)''. On envelope: ''#465 Hayutin Family''.

Anna Ginsberg Hayutin sits with her hands folded on her lap. She wears an elaborate hat and a long dress with lace at the collar and sleeves. Anna Ginsberg was born in Russia but came to New York City with her parents, D'vera and Max Ginsberg. They moved to Denver in 1910 when she was still a young girl. Anna married the son of Russian immigrants, businessman Morris Hayutin, who owned the Western Supply Company and later the Public Industrial Bank.
Donated by Peryle Hayutin Beck.
